details:
I remember that one of the things that first drew me into High Fidelity was a vision that Philip Rosedale had as far back as 2013. Here's a quote from a Silicon Valley VR Meetup from July of 2013:

"And then the second thing. as I said, is to somehow build a system in which perhaps the majority or all of the servers aside from simply being decentralized or distributed are actually running on machines at home and using idle resources because Second life has, I said 40,000 cores and typically about 100,000 online. So you've got less machines than you do people. That are being serviced by those machines, basically. What if we could use your extra machines while you were asleep? If you do the math on that I think you could have ten times as many machines as as people. So its something like it could be as much as a two order magnitude of change in the amount of machine power that we have."
title: Lost Vision: Federated Computing

details:
At this time, FSTs are directly hosted and accessed from a web source, and the information about the hosted location is sent out to everyone under the AvatarData property skeletonModelURL.

This feature request is an option to allow the Avatar Mixer to become a temporary host for the requested FST, acting as a proxy to the real FST. This would allow users to still get the information they need while also blocking the direct URL of where the FST is stored (preventing direct avatar copying). This can also help users who may have a stronger connection to the server rather than the host spot of the avatar.

In addition, this can also act as a better way of enforcing avatar whitelists or blocking uncertified avatars, as the FST information can be filtered in advance.

The basic process would be as follows:
1.	User joins a domain and sends the avatar mixer their skeletonModelURL (MyAvatar).
2.	Avatar mixer downloads and stores the FST in cache.
3.	The FST url given to other users is based on the FST in cache (avatar:///{SESSION-ID}.fst).
4.	Other users process FST as usual (grab FBX, textures, etc).

An obvious challenge is having the avatar mixer check the FST and add any missing information (ie: resolving local urls to global urls), but since the assignment-client should have access to the same parser interface does, this shouldn’t be too complicated.
title: Offer the Avatar Mixer to proxy FST URLs for added avatar security

details:
Currently, the current KTX tools do not offer any kind of deflation of texture files, resulting in increased bandwidth costs when on slower networks. The Kronos format is capable of deflating the textures and could result in possible 50% reductions in file sizes without loss to quality, further benefiting the use of baking objects and avatars.

While Basis/Crunch is not available, zlib and ANS compression on image textures are completed.

https://github.com/KhronosGroup/KTX-Specification/blob/master/ktxspec.adoc#38-supercompressionscheme
title: Add compression to KTX textures (baking/oven related)

details:
According to John Carmack, CTO of Oculus: "Use MSAA for rendering. Not using MSAA should be an immediate fail for any app submission" ... "In general, using MSAA means you can't use a deferred rendering engine. You don't want to for performance reasons, anyway."

One of the common criticisms of High Fidelity is how blurry it is, and switching to forward rendering is the solution so that MSAA can be used. I know a forward renderer is already in the works for mobile, but I think it needs to be default on both mobile and desktop for performance and quality reasons. The benefits of deferred are outweighed by the problems it causes in VR.
title: Switch from Deferred to Forward rendering on PC

comments.value: Actually, if I remember, Forward rendering IS what is used on the mobile device.

I think there's more value in finishing the proper non-broken blurry mess TAA implementation (https://github.com/highfidelity/hifi/pull/13246) since having played with it, I think it does get pretty close to the expectations people probably have of decent quality anti-aliasing (it's actually using the velocity buffer for one thing). There are some other issues related to a deferred pipeline such as an ability to control per-surface shading which outright excludes correct implementations of several real-world and stylized rendering models (http://filmicworlds.com/blog/materials-that-need-forward-shading/), but these edge-cases can still be made available by allowing specifically marked surfaces to bypass the deferred shading model and write directly to the emission output.

Honestly though, I would say a more appropriate attitude to take to this, even if it does incur greater engineering overhead, is not assuming there is such a thing as a one-size fits all solution for a platform which is designed to hold a lot of appeal to artists coming from a variety of styles, which might make it appropriate to even allowing things like domains (or even zones?) to specify a preference for certain kinds of rendering models where it might make more technical sense; a world for example which is primarily using baked lighting is probably not going to benefit from the overhead of a deferred pipeline.

details:
Right now, we only have two lock properties: on and off. When active, the properties of an entity cannot be modified until someone (or something) with lock/unlock permissions unlocks the object. If a server script is trying to modify an object, it must first unlock it, then perform the modifications, in addition to re-establishing the lock.

This feature request is to add a third and forth state: server locked, which means that any edit requests from a client/interface are ignored and only the server's edits are acknowledged (except for the state itself, where a user does have permission to enable/disable this) and self modifiable lock, meaning that only edits from scripts included on the object  or the owner of the object are acknowledged.

The basic idea behind these two states are to moderate what edits are performed so there are no windows for tampering. This would allow a user to lock down a wall clock, for example, but the wall clock can still operate without having to unlock itself every time, as edits from users are denied, except for those with the special unlock/lock permissions. Likewise, objects that are designed to be interactable by the owner and the owner only don't have to run checks if someone or something else modified it unless someone again has special permissions.
title: Create new Lock Types: Server Modifiable Lock and Self Modifiable Lock

details: At the moment, the "Export Entity" and "Export Selection" will make a generic json file. However, some assumptions can be made depending on your intentions. For example, if you are exporting a wearable, you might want it to automatically use jointIndexName instead of jointIndexNumber which will use the name of the bone the wearable is attached to rather than a number, which can be different on all avatars.  This will also create further compatibility between avatars with wearables. Hats for example. Most avatars will have a bone simply called "head."  Using the command mentioned above in the auto-generated json will ensure the hat attaches to head. This could also be another place to set parameters such as grabbable, collisions, etc, as you cannot reach the create menu without domain permissions.
title: Templates for "Export Entities"

details: Will be very useful to have the option to allow access of users based on their registered email address. Let say I want to create an event and I want to invite some people to attend. I have their emails, and I send the invitations. Because I don't know their HiFi usernames, or they don't have one yet, it is impossible to create the access policy. If we will have this option, we can send the invitations to their emails and they will register HiFi accounts using that emails and have access to the event.
title: Security:  Permissions for Speciffic Users based on emails.

comments.value:
I really like this idea, but I think that it would have to be implemented very carefully. If the domain server itself is able to see people's email addresses, there is the potential that someone could exploit this and possibly get the email addresses of all those who visit their domain whether or not those users have their email publicly visible. 

Maybe there could be a section in the domain settings panel which is labeled something like "permissions for users from email addresses" which acts similar to permissions for users from IP addresses but rather than having the domain server check that the emails match, it sends that data off to a server hosted by HiFi which then returns with a positive or negative. This might add a few extra milliseconds to the time it takes users with email based permissions to connect but I think it's a fair trade-off.

The above solution does have its own problems, though, such as the fact that if for some reason HiFi's servers were unreachable this would not work at all.

This is really not a good idea. First, not all users have emails that were used on sign up (steam sign ins, for example). Secondly, this could easily lead to privacy issues where the server is asking for outside information for validation. It'd make finding out people's email addresses a no brainer through process of elimination.

Plus, later on, it may become a thing where more user accounts are made using alternative sign in methods, like Google, Facebook (BLEGH), Twitter, etc. In all those cases, emails wouldn't be involved.

@flamesoulis: You are right Flame, but in mine case I already know the email addresses so it is not a privacy issue. Also when I will send invitations I will specify that the accounts must be created based on this email.

Another posible aproach will be to have the access based on a password. When an user enter to a domain a password prompt form will be displayed and based on his response will be or not accepted to enter.

title: Avatar theft is a problem
details:
I was told to make this canny post after emailing support due to a user stealing my avatar. Avatar theft is too easy, and it doesn't get punished.

I know avatars can easily be stolen via script. I don't know how it works, but I've seen it happen. Many users have had it happen to them. Maybe a more technical user could elaborate in the comments. I uploaded and submitted my avatar through the marketplace, I got it verified, I got myself a certificate. Why did I bother going through all of that?

Also, the rules are not strict enough on avatar theft. The greeters could not ban the person who was proven to have been stealing them (Not attacking the greeters, I know they're just following the rules). It should be clearly against the terms of service to steal someones avatar without their permission.

I'm not a good programmer, I don't know how to fix this. But the other platforms seem to do avatar protection better than Hifi does, so I know that more could be done. This hurts creators, and it hurts High Fidelity when creators don't want to use a platform that can't give their work reasonable protections.

comments.value:
First of all, I already have a function in my pentesting toolkit just for doing this. It's so easy it's not even funny, but even if we leave scripting out, the ability to steal or distribute avatar URLs that are purchased from the marketplace can be done very easily and I have already reported how (hint: spend time with the avatar app some more).

I have already made two canny requests in regards to this issue, both of which are still untouched:
http://roadmap.highfidelity.com/feature-requests/p/port-certified-entity-protection-to-the-avatar-mixer

http://roadmap.highfidelity.com/feature-requests/p/make-avatar-certificates-readable

Also, during all meetings, the topic of content protection always boils down to High Fidelity's complete unwillingness to do anything because "memory readers can be used." First of all, you are right; protecting against memory readers like OpenGL Intercept is impossible. Do you also know that most people are unlikely to use it? The idea with content protection is to make it more annoying to copy something than it is worth just to buy legit without increasing the difficulty to use as a legit owner. Take a tour of how music distribution changed and you should see what I mean.

I have offered High Fidelity a few basic options, in addition to the above suggestions, and we can all see the outcome. Hifi has been stating a demand for content and users but can't get both if content creators are unwilling to distribute on a platform that offers no protection and a platform that doesn't have content won't attract users.

At this time, the only benefit the marketplace has is to allow things to be purchased, but only offers protections for entities on a basic level. Avatars, despite past discussions regarding unique avatars forming identities, are given absolutely no protections nor the ability to inspect the authenticity of them. I have no reason to put any avatars on the marketplace, be it ones I personally own or ones that could be marketed with my connections, due to the lack of willingness to protect creators.

I've just figured it out myself, its doable with 3 console commands. It's ridiculously easy.

EDIT: It's doable with ONE console command. This is super easy.

I had my avatar stolen, and since I made it myself it's completely unique and everyone who comes across it will see that as "me".
Due to how HiFi works people thought I just appeared as offline and chose a different nickname and was weirded out when "I" wouldn't respond to them, except for one individual who caught on and told me later what happened.

It's discouraging to me how easy it is to pretend to be someone else, in my case I was just lucky the person who stole my avatar wasn't intentionally trying to do me harm. But what if he wanted to ruin my reputation? 

Avatar theft is a bigger deal in HiFi in my opinion because how easy it is to appear as someone else. If someone else used my unique avatar in any other social VR app then at least my identity wouldn't be mistaken, because you cannot change your name as frequently or easy (or at all).

Seeing how HiFi apparently doesn't want to combat this or take this seriously doesn't make me want to upload my newer avatars to the platform or recommend my non-HiFi friends to upload theirs. Obviously avatar theft do occur on other platforms aswell, but at least those platforms actually punish those users and actively engage in the endless cat-and-mouse chase to at least make it way more difficult to do so.

We're currently scoping something to address this pain point. In short, if someone attempts to wear an avatar that is certified on the blockchain, that individual will be visually apparent to all other users in the domain that they are wearing a stolen avatar. Unfortunately, there's no way for us to completely prevent avatar theft, but we hope this will discourage and reduce theft.
@emily-iwankovitsch: This, along with making avatar certificates viewable, or at least making it viewable if someone has a certificate at all, could solve impersonation issues.

title: WebEntity Audio Improvements
details: Currently on Windows, WebEntities playing audio will output their audio directly to the default system audio device, not the audio device selected in High Fidelity's audio settings. This can prove problematic on an Oculus Rift setup where Oculus does not attempt to change the default audio device in the way SteamVR does. You can hear this problem most noticeably by going to a WebPanel streaming audio not hearing anything, only hearing it when opening up the Dash. Going further, it would be even better if we could even output to spatial audio sources for sophisticated surround sound setups which would significantly improve High Fidelity as a viable platform for streaming.

comments.value: Everyone always complains that they can't hear what everyone else hears. It's a big deal when you're trying to do a video screening.

Okay, I kind of want to post a follow up to this based on the fact that I've been digging into the source code find out exactly how the behavior of WebEntity audio works, and what I've discovered is interesting. High Fidelity already has code in place which should make audio output of WebEntities respect the interface settings, and it most cases it does...except with certain media players, such the ones I've seen in Caitlyn and Maki's domains. I'm not sure exactly how to classify this now, whether it's a bug; it's certainly unexpected and undesired behavior, but it looks to be something potentially more deeply-rooted in web standards.

Even so, regardless of when this gets fixed, it would still be really nice to have WebEntities write audio data to a stream, which would then facilitate elaborate audio spatialisation and surround-sound setups in VR.

title: Client Side Script Whitelist
details:
This has been a topic that was suggested ages ago by HumbleTim, and 
parroted by me a few times already in various meetings over the years.

But keeps falling "down the cracks" over these years of community meetings, posts on forums,
So, Parroting again.

I have usually brought up this same exploit many times, and demonstrated it MANY TIMES.
Be it through foxbombs, targeted foxlasers, wallet opening panics, wanted posters, among other mischievous pranks to raise awareness.

But as High Fidelity has grown; 
which has caused the exploits are getting serious, or damaging; which can be damning as more and more money is getting involved.

I am afraid of just nodding at the direction "The exploit you described" is just waiting for murphys law to kick in:

So, I'll open the can of worms.

I mean the can was already open, It actually starting to reek,
but I am turning it upside down and laying its contents on a plate with a solution how to address it.
 There are already protections in place for most HiFi run domains (Except, Maker), which is why this is ok time to talk about it in more depth.

....

Most attack vectors for "Exploits" as discussed in the town meeting on 14 March 19 involve running an
entity script that targets a specific users (this is fairly simple to do). 
It's not even an exploit, it is the main feature, which can, and has been exploited.

Lets describe the crux of it:

You can edit ANY UNLOCKED ENTITY. There is no such thing as "edit permission". You can do this with a client script or a modified create script.

The nature of Hifi requires interactable objects to be unlocked, so you cant really lock everything. 
If things were locked, theyd be static. You cant do anything with a locked entity, except unlock it, if you have the permission to do so. So LOCKED Entities do have domain level protection which is a good thing.

However, for unlocked entities, this means you can apply any entity script to any unlocked object; unless the server denies you this through filters.

Entity scripts are scripts that run locally on your client and allows it impact you, or command you to impact the world. So if you fire a flare gun up in the sky? You create the entity, simulate it, and definite the particle and light effects for other clients. Hook guns? it applies an force to your avatar, pushing it forward along the hookline.

This is how many things in High Fidelity works. You have an input and have an output. Make sense right? Flow.js is a fantastic example of a client script that animates your avatar depending on the your avatar and other avatars.

Combined with Message Queue, you can do... many great things... and many unspeakable things with this.
Such as take over control of another user's actions. 
And if targeted to a specific user you can be them, at least according to the server.

All things great power comes with great responsibility; and with everyone having such power, you shouldn't just trust everyone.

....

Scripts are the lifeblood of High Fidelity, without them we have the fun things, they sorta need to have the unferreted access;
Permissions systems like SL or Android would be nice to have, but have architectural challenges ahead and may take years to establish, 
which does not address the short-term (even if alphas been discussing this longer than a few years).

Most of this can be protected against via Entity Filters, and fairly all High Fidelity domains are protected by them,
meaning places like Spot and Bank are fairly secure, (i will keep poking ;) ).
These tend to work by only allowing certain edits (like position, rotation) to be trasmitted to other users, with everything else being "locked".

But Filters are an arcane art and not well documented for others to make full use of.

They are also not provided by default in the sandboxes provided to users.

----

So.. If youd eliminate the client from running a malicious script, 
then youd eliminate this attack vector: 

It is a Matter of Trust. 
Thus we need to be able to define that trust through Client Script Whitelists.

The white list should also be extendable by user, allowing one to add their own scripts to the list. But this should only affect that user.

By Default, what everyone should have theirs running at.
You should Only trust following scripts:

1. Released (Stressing REVIEWED) marketplace scripts. (Marketplace Authorized)
2. Scripts or url domains that the domain say are ok. (Domain Authorized, or Required)
3. Scripts from file system. (Local filesystem)

Users should be able to turn on / off which ever. If a domain requires scripts to run on the domain, they should be allowed to run on client. If client denies these from running then client should immediately disconnect and give a message to user that the domain requires the permission to connect. (This allows for gamelogic, and I think is already in place)

This can later be expanded upon with a permission system that analyses what commands the script will run; and if permissions are given, will allow it to be placed on the whitelist. Ofcourse there are some stuff that should never be allowed to go through such, such as presence of eval.


This does not eliminate bad actor domains, but it would put more control for the client. 
IT would also put more people in ease of not bumping into entities that may do something naughty with their clients.

title: ability to move camera independently of avatar
details:
This would be particularly useful when building wearable attachment points for marketplace items. 

It seems the best way currently is to go into the create menu to move things around, but the camera is still locked in all modes other than ~"move with avatar".

When looking at the avatar or things worn by the avatar being able to move the camera would be superb.

Perhaps I am missing something and a recommended workflow exists already? Please chime in with tips anyone!

comments.value: This would be useful. Would you prefer flycam like most game engines have or select/lock on and orbit around like 3D modelling software navigation?

There is functionality to move your camera around, but it sadly isn't very obvious.

Start by selecting an object with the Create tools open.

Make sure that your current view mode is first or third person.

Then hit the F key on your keyboard. I tend to think of this as the "Focus" key. The camera should move so that the object that you have selected is centered in your view.

While in this mode, holding down the right mouse button and moving your mouse will rotate around the selected object.

Holding down your middle mouse button (the wheel on most mice) and moving the mouse you can pan around the object.

Holding down the ALT key, and then dragging on one of the arrows will make a copy of the currently selected object.

There may be more, but this is what I'm aware of. 

@emily-iwankovitsch: This is an opportunity to improve documentation regarding the use of the camera while the creation tools are active.
@marcusllewellyn-1: thanks Marcus!
This is SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO importent!!!!!!!!! for building and just in general. "fluffy" has a great script for this. http://fluffy.ws/HighFid/inspect.js

Couple things:

1) There are several powerful scripting APIs that allow you to do exactly this. And I see from LAGraff's comment that fluffy and other users have used those APIs to create different camera UX/tools.... that's great! That's what we designed those APIs for.

2) We are looking at making a couple of new camera controls for the create tools that will probably meet your asks. We don't have a date for this yet, but it is planned.

3) Finally, we are also planning on making some improvements to the 3rd person camera which in some cases might also meet your asks.

So in general: feel free to use the APIs to write your own controls (and maybe even add it to the marketplace). AND... stay tuned from some new camera controls coming soon.
We are planning improvements to the camera controls while in edit mode.

title: Port certified entity protection to the avatar mixer
details:
At this time, purchased entities from the marketplace only allow the entities to exist in one domain at a time and only for one copy. This adds the properties itemName, itemDescription, itemCategories, itemArtist,  itemLicense, limitedRun, editionNumber, entityInstanceNumber, marketplaceID, certificateID, and staticCertificateVersion. These properties all involve the marketplace certification system to help prove authenticity and help avoid copying in normal use cases (ignoring URL acquisition and what not).

What I propose is having a similar set of conditions to be passed to the avatar class (Avatar/MyAvatar). This could then be coupled into the avatar mixer, where if a certified marketplace avatar is worn, only the owner can wear it. If a user copies the skeletonURL to themselves, the avatar mixer could deny its use, either by showing a woodie avatar (in T-Pose to avoid joint index differences) and/or other action (informing the client the URL is invalid).

In addition, this would help pave the way for "Make Avatar Certificates readable" (http://roadmap.highfidelity.com/feature-requests/p/make-avatar-certificates-readable) while beginning to put the initial steps towards avatar security, as at this time, nothing stops a user from wearing a certified avatar they don't own. This could also introduce a new domain-server property to only allow certified avatars much like the ability to (temp)Rez certified items vs normal (temp)Rez.

title: Allow users to control volume defined by audio zones
details:
I was at the spot last night and there were people playing music near the money tree and I was talking to people at help. The helper thought this was a neat idea too since it's a hassle to always lower the volume of people playing music.

comments.value: I think the most elegant way of implementing it is to use the zone as a multiplier for the volume of that zone. This way, if I reduced someone's volume by 50% and I reduced the volume of the zone they are in by 50%, then their volume would be 25%. This would minimize all the extra work on the audio mixer by keeping a small array per user of the zones.

I'd also like to mention that this wouldn't break immersion as it is defined by the server. If I wanted to create a cinema, I would absolutely not give the users the ability to control the volume of the screen. I wouldn't want people talking over a movie out loud.

title: Entity Server Scripts can lock/unlock entities no matter who created it
details: On my domain, locking and unlocking entities is a permission I only gave to myself. Nobody else should be able to unlock or lock entities. An entity client script wouldn't be able to unlock or lock an entity if the user who ran the script didn't have the permission to do so. But using a server entity script, which anyone can put on an unlocked object, you can lock or unlock any entity in the domain even if you don't have permission to do so. This is clearly not something I want other users to be able to do, and the only solution is to block all scripts, or lock all objects, which is unrealistic.

title: Domain admins cannot see or ban users who have blocked them.

On my domain, I'm the only one with access to the server website. Any other admin is powerless if a troll just blocks them.

The domain admins would also have to rely on other users to report a troll, because the admin(s) can't even see what the user is doing.

This seems like a potential major issue. Domain admins should not be blockable, all users should be visible so that the admins can do their jobs.

title: Permanent mute :X
details:
Our community is growing, and its a fact of life not every one is going to get alone. some people will end up bumping heads. 
Some people may just not like a person or what they says or a group of people. 

Currently the ignore feature just does not work, and this is really effecting our community members directly. 
When a person is ignored they can leave the domain and be rendered again by the person who wanted to ignore them. 
There have been issues where some users have been using scripts to manipulate this loop hole and rerender them self's each time a person ignore them.
In order to prevent this users have created a script that will persistently ignore them. 

So now we have a case where users are having an endless war of trying to ignore each other. In some of these cases 
a user can only take some much and this leads to outbursts. This has really but a rock in the path of our communities wellbeing. 

When the hifi team has a chance it would really help the community to really look further into making the ignore feature permanent, and even the ability to 
unblock them again in the case the two parties kiss and make up. 

:3 dont block me bro

comments.value:
This has really been an ongoing issue and while complicated, should be resolved with utmost care and importance.

A solution could be to offer 'sub-sessions' that servers can see, but others cannot. This session could be generated on user entry and even though the session ID is different, the server's session ID carries over until the client fully quits out or other conditions are met. This would help keep anonymity (since only the server itself can see the 'server session' ID) and could allow for 'persistent' properties (like the server knowing who to keep ignore settings on).

However, another solution could be to have the client send a list of 'ignored users' and have the server work that way. The only issue is how to safely store these properties without exposing them to the client itself.

title: Improved ForeArm IK (aka no more wrist crunch)
details:
At the moment, the current arm IK has the arms locked specifically to meet the position of the hand. Turning the hand/wrist will not alter the arm IK at all, even if the hand is flipped completely. This makes items like watches impractical.

The request is for the forearm IK to rotate or have its rotation influenced by the roll of the hand, which would allow for slightly better realism, less wrist crunching, and make apparel items like watches work better.

EDIT: That also being said, realizing this could make robotic avatars not work too well, perhaps it may be best to also have this adjustable on the avatar's FST... or maybe we just need a wrist bone? I'd hate to recommend the latter since that could screw up a lot of avatars by changing the current avatar skeleton like that.

title: Make Avatar Certificates readable
details: At this time, only static objects can be inspected. Avatars, however, cannot be checked for authenticity. Please add some way of proving that a person's worn avatar is authentic.

I wonder if there’s a signal that could be fired when userData is changes that I can access in my code, this would be a better way of doing it.

title: Enable playing of Internet Radio stations
details:
I want to be able to stream internet radio. Personally I want to be able to add DI.FM audio streams to my world, though I realize that's almost certainly a niche format. The provide the following formats so any of those that are also used elsewhere would be good:

MP3: 320 kbits/sec
AAC: 128 kbits/sec
AAC-HE: 64 kbits/sec

comments.value: Ogg radio station work in hifi and you can find a lot of them on ice cast directory and Maki has a webpanel that makes it easy to do so.

I would love a system whereby one could drop a shoutcast/icecast stream link into a zone's properties and that stream would play for anyone who entered it. A user made an application for this a long time ago, and I absolutely loved it. It was similar in many ways to Second Life's streaming media system which to this day allows thousands of DJs and other musicians to share music at venues all over the Grid. The system that a user had made was in my opinion far better than Linden Lab's implementation and even allowed users to share streams with one another without needing a zone at all... Then one day an update to HiFi rolled out which resulted in permanent loss of audio output if you stopped (Or started? I can't remember which) a stream.

title: Add more options to the oven
details:
I would like to have control over the quality and resolution of the textures baked with oven.exe, and possibly through the asset server. I don't know if this already exists with the command line.

In Unity, I crunch my textures to get the file sizes down. I don't want people to have to download 100-200mb worth of textures. It would be great if I could control the amount of compression/lossyness/quality, whatever the proper word is.

I think it would also be handy to specify resolution per platform. I wouldn't want to use 4K maps on mobile, so it would be handy to be able to choose resolution of the mobile and desktop textures.

title: Separate create app into two different apps for the different create use cases
details:
There are really two very different 'create' scenarios for VR worlds and currently High Fidelity doesn't have the best UI for either of them.

The first scenario is what Anyland or Tiltbrush does. You provide tools for creating objects in VR based on simple shapes. The UI for this is an object on one hand that you can use to select and create objects (like the shapes app).

The second scenario is when you are adding objects that have been created elsewhere and your main goal is to orient, size and place them in the scene. The best examples of this UI are currently TheWave and Oculus Home. What's required for this is a visual way to scan through all the objects you own (and maybe directly marketplace too) and really easily place them in the scene. Things like snap to grid or snap to object massively help this.

Maybe there's a third use case like the current create app that only gets activated for power users that need the fine control, but this is currently quite a pain to use in VR mode.

title: Ability to access files in approved marketplace item
details: You should be able to access the files for items you created in the marketplace that have been approved. I've moved computers and don't have access to old files so would like to retrieve things from the cloud where they are stored.

title: Allow locking of individual parameters and/or sections of an Entity
details: Sometimes with entities I don't want to lock the whole thing, just parts of it. For example, locking the scripts, user data, and ability to be deleted, while still allowing the object to be picked up and thrown around. Locking the scale and rotation of an object, but allowing it to be moved. The current lock would become more of a "Lock All". I know that this is already technically possible with filters, but making it a checkbox in the interface would make things a lot quicker and easier.

comments.value: Currently scoping

title: Option to specify domain-server http/https port
details:
At this time, the domain-server always opens 40100 and 40101 for http and https access to the control panel respectively. The assignment-client's ports can be specified, while the domain-server's http(s) ports cannot be adjusted without recompiling the executable.

Would it be possible to add command line options to also change the http/http ports of the domain server (--http-port --https-port)?

title: Ogg Vorbis, better MP3 VBR and FLAC support
details:
Playing audio as an injector doesn't support Ogg Vorbis which is a free codec used by big services like Spotify. It's confusing why it's not supported because it's free and it encodes audio very transparently.

Then with MP3 VBR I've seen in the logs that it plays at a lower bitrate at 128kb/s. Using music from Bandcamp in MP3 VBR V0 and MP3 CBR 320kb/s, the constant bitrate sounded much better even though they sounded the exact same playing them in an audio player.

Then FLAC support would be pretty awesome since it's free aswell!

comments.value: Maki, you are saying that if you have a Spotify account, they give you direct access to an Ogg Vorbis encoded file/stream?  Can you send me where that is in their API docs?
With MP3 now being free for everyone (the last patents expired last year if I remember), our understanding/expectation is that Vorbis will disappear as a format.

No, you can't get the Ogg stream directly from Spotify but using networking tools and with some research, I've realized that they use that format. I'm sure Vorbis is definitely not disappearing as a format because many people find it superior than Mp3. It's also VBR by default making it smaller and can be streamed easily.

title: Mute microphone set by default
details: Muting should be a default, or at least have a checkbox for the user to select. As in real life, its rude to enter a room or theater making sounds like eating or keyboard clicks for everyone in the space.

comments.value: @billmar - are you saying that you'd like something beyond the Mute / UnMute features that you have currently? If so can you provide a little more insight here?

title: High Fidelity for the Vive Focus
details: This work will overlap getting Hifi running on the Oculus Quest, since the units are similar and run on Android.  Expect launch soon of new unit with 6DOF tracking and hand controllers.

title: High Fidelity for the Oculus Quest
details:
Create a version that runs well on the Quest, enabling many new people starting in mid-2019 to be able to visit High Fidelity. 

This is substantial work to the rendering engine, as the Quest GPU is 5x slower than the PC.

comments.value: We're actively working on this.

This will be a pretty big deal in general, the user base for the Quest is potentially very large. So if a 'high fidelity' experience can be given that doesn't crash nearly as often, then I think it will really help HiFi gain steam and a healthy flow of new users.
How can we optimize for Quest? Are there any guidelines we could try to follow? Anyway we can test our domains?
@1029chris: Yes, we will include this in docs.  High level, optimizations for Quest will mean using baked lighting instead of local lights, and less texture detail.

@philip-47: Would multiple realtime lights even be be possible on mobile? Maybe through per vertex lights or realtime light probes? All current domains and props are designed around realtime lights, it would be nice if they worked on mobile, even if they didn't look the best. I know on the current android version real time lights are just disabled.

Also, is baking something that Hifi will eventually do, or will I have to go do it in another program and bring in the lightmaps?
Having 'high' hopes for this (^_^)

title: Embedded domains and portals
details:
Allow me to place a live 3D copy of another domain anywhere inside my own domain, or alternatively, a live doorway to another domain.  Looking from one domain into another in this way, you will see the actual people that are there. 

This will be the metaverse equivalent of the hyperlink - a way for server operators to connect to each other and create huge spaces.  

For example, a city made of one domain could have a skypscraper where every apartment was it's own domain, etc.  

A single 'Starbucks' domain could be embedded in hundreds of other domains, and when you walk inside from anywhere you find the same people. 

This feature will help connect servers into a larger whole.

comments.value: Mind blown
I love this idea so much! It would be so cool. Would the whole server be embedded or just a part of it?
@1029chris: Either.  As the creator of the embedded domain, you would be able to re-size the portion of the target domain that you wanted to appear in your own.

title: Entities.clearJointData
details: Currently, when you set a joint on an entity, it will set the rotation or translation of that joint, but will continue to keep it with no way to reset the joint back to normal without doing a complex array reset. It would be nice if there was a MyAvatar.clearJointData equivalent to more easily reset a joint back to normal.

title: Add Full Maya workflow support
details:
I have looked through the documents here on the site and I cant seem to find much to any in terms of full support for Maya on here. A lot of the mentions for Avatars alone mention Blender only which, while some things say Maya on the files, no examples are given or etc unlike Blender for Avatars. Past maybe Objects, there is nothing about Avatar support for Maya or how to go about properly (Text below explains why I said properly) exporting from Maya into High Fidelity using the FBX method.

I happen to use Maya a LOT, its my go-to-tool right now and I have even used it for Game Production for both College and out-of-college use and indie works. I flat out do not use Blender enough to take time to do all the added steps that would take me less than a hour to do in Maya-- especially when other engines support Maya out of the box like Unreal and Unity... Many of my attempts to use Maya FBX files with High Fidelity has lead to many errors (Size and complete figure displacement) and/or complete system crashes of the client to the point of total frustration.

The lack of any official info regarding this lead me to making this request; Can we please get some sort of official workflow support for Maya users. I really want to support and make content for this game-- many do. However I just do not have the time to just re-learn a program process that would take way too much of my time to do in another program when the one I do have not only works out of the box for other similar programs but also similar games.

comments.value:
I'm a Blender user, and it is a breath of fresh air to find a platform that treats Blender as first class software.

However, I do run into too many people using Maya that can't be helped by Blender users. While we can describe a general procedure, specifics for Maya's user interface and components require a recommendation to track down another user of Maya.

I'm also unaware of anyone putting in any effort to smooth workflows with Maya scripting. This has been a marvelous boon to Blender users.

I anticipate that being able to make use of glTF for avatars will ease FBX headaches for users of both Blender and Maya.

title: Improved Entity-Parenting
details: Currently, setting entities to be parented by another is cumbersome, and a tree-based representation might make this a lot easier to work with. More importantly though, the scaling between parented objects is not treated as relative. I am aware that there would probably be issues with reflecting this in the underlying collision engine which would not make perfect entity-scaling completely possible, but the engine should at least try to compensate the best it can. This would also make better interoperability with other engines possible.

comments.value: I'd love a tree style view of parented stuff, rather than having all the items be in one big list. Would make things easier to organize as well if entities could be thrown into a group then collapsed. My world entity list is a mess.

One challenge is that things parented probably have to treated together for rendering and LOD so there is a difference between using this as a compound object creator tool,  versus organizing everything in a whole domain/scene.  Otherwise, we agree this needs to get done and it's on our list.
It would also be nice to see the children in the properties window currently you can only see the parent.
this is SO CRITICAL. Including compounding collision hulls.

title: roadtohifi sorting feature
details: allow users to sort requests they have made. allowing them to see only post they have made in order to track progress

title: wearables to be used across domains
details: from what i gathered if i put up wearables in my domain. i wont be able to wear them outside of my domain or high fidelity domains. i can understand this being a issue concerning trolls who wear items that are not suitable for welcome. but it would be nice to have a system where we are allowed to make wearables like in body mart in avatar worlds.

comments.value:
You can do that already. If a wearable is made into an actual wearable (not equipable) and the item is from an http source, then it should carry over.

The thing is, what you are currently describing is a bit like what happened with Avatar Island, where walking out with what you have on is not intended at all.

title: Allow Minified Code on Marketplace
details:
Currently on the Marketplace Submissions Rules, "No minified code, it should be human readable and well documented. No obfuscated or unintelligible code is allowed."

This is pretty unfair to coders. I can understand having to submit a review copy of the code, but having the marketplace item's code fully documented and unprotected is like asking all models to include their source files.

I can understand that obfuscated code not be allowed until things such as a permission system is added, but the marketplace should at least offer to minify code post  approval. Otherwise, scripted items might as well be open source.

comments.value: This could also present a barrier for languages that transpile to JavaScript like TypeScript or CoffeeScript. These can introduce complex code in an effort to implement things like async that no average JavaScripter is going to easily comprehend.

iv heard hifi dosnt have the personal to review all the obfuscated  scripts that would come through market. if the team could review the obfuscated code we would see a nice script boom (that would be breaking on updates).

I would go as far as to expand the scope of this request to allow external scripts - to a degree. There could be a vetting process and reputable developers would be allowed to do this if they were pre-approved to.

Any app without the ability to access outside persistent data is going to be very limited in scope. Communications, settings, all kinds of data. I mean hifi already need it to run things like the Bingo domain.

On the bright side ... if the entire marketplace requires non-minified code that could make code theft, the thing you fear for a lot harder. So if someone obviously stole your code without permission and the marketplace would police this then they wouldn't be able to sell your work as theirs on the marketplace.

There are pros and cons to everything, whereas a minified script could simply be included without such protection. Or rather someone could take your hard work, minify it and then sell it as their own and you wouldn't really be able to tell.

There are arguments for both sides here, it's not as black and white.

Or after scripts are approved they could be minified automatically and only the minified served to users. Then we submit human readable code, but only the minified is served but it's not required to submit multiple versions of hte code which is even more overhead for creating submissions.
We are currently revising our submission guidelines and this is part of that.

title: Marketplace Adult Content
details:
It would be nice to have an "adult" checkbox for marketplace submissions. Any such items could for the time being not be listed on the marketplace at all, but still be sold from domains with people who get the direct link. That way creators can take advantage of the current tools and processes in place of the marketplace without going against the current submission policy for no adult content.

I assume there will be people who want to see this. I certainly do. Again this would depend on management I guess, vision and timing, hence why the suggestion is to have the items not listed on the marketplace at all instead of having them on a separate adult listing, which could be a secondary step in the future.

comments.value:
We think the work needed here looks like: 

1.   Add an 'adult' tag to marketplace items. 
2.  Add a setting to allow server operators to not allow adult-tagged content.
3.  Ability to filter what is seen in 'goto' page by whether adult content is allowed on the server.  

Thoughts?
@philip-47: Question, if someone made a nude model that they cover up with clothing wearables, would the nude model be considered adult?
@1029chris: Great point.  Need to consider that in design.  Behavior (removing clothing, etc) can be considered adult without the models necessarily being as such.

@philip-47: But also, you'd only want adults to be able to browse and purchase nude models on the store. So they'd have to be marked as adult in some way. Maybe there could be some way for clothing to deactivate the adult status of an avatar?

I also think there's a difference between domains which allow adult content and domains which are for porn. Some server owners will encourage adult activities to happen out in public and have it be the main focus of their domain, while others will be okay with it happening on their server as long as they take it to a private room and stay out of sight.

@1029chris: Actually, this is a lot like Second Life with the difference between Mature and Adult... at least during when we had to ask years ago.

Mature was basically 'nude is okay, just don't do anything sexual' with adult being 'anything goes.' As such, it allowed sims that sold 'junk' to be sold without issue as long as the advertisement did not show them in use. Things that would be used for porn would be in adult sims.

That being said, based on Hifi's current rating system would technically allow for this, since SL only had 3 teirs (PG, Mature, Adult) with Hifi having 5 (Everyone, Teen, Mature, Adult, and Unrated). In this case, Everyone would be PG; Teen would be no nude, but more risque would be okay; Mature would match SL's mature (tits are okay, but don't juggle them), with Adult filling out the obvious. The only one that would be up for debate is Unrated.

With all that being said, as High Fidelity Inc operates the current placename ICE system, it would be up to them to establish the rules of the varying maturity ratings. Obviously, having the marketplace system follow it would create a tough issue for Mature and Adult due to how close of a threshold each is at (17+ vs 18+), which could impact domain operation as well (assuming the domain operator isn't limited to a Mature domain only allowing up to Mature items when some items could be viewed or advertised as Adult when not actually used up to that rating).

@flamesoulis: What I meant is more like, what about a domain that only allows sexual stuff in a secluded area away from everyone else? Perhaps it's a single building that its allowed in, while anywhere else it's against the rules. Compare that to a domain that allows sexual stuff anywhere out in the open. Would they get the same rating? Perhaps specific zones could be rated adult rather than the entire server?
@1029chris: That sounds more like the domain zones system in all honesty. I guess with a script, you could enforce rules with zones but I digress.

title: Optimise audio injectors for slower upload speeds
details: Since I recently updated to a much faster internet speed, I thought I should raise some awareness about certain aspects of the platform which are problematic for those with much slower ADSL connections and may risk turning many users away. The biggest culprit for problems in this regard are audio injectors, used for things such eating in The Spot and using the Money Tree. These audio injectors basically use a much larger than necessary amount of bandwidth and can cause those with slower upload speeds to frequently lose connection with the server.

comments.value: Perhaps even recode the items to use server-side audio injectors. No downloads needed for the clients and chances are the resources are already on the server itself. Plus the server wouldn't need to do any extra processing: it IS the audio mixer, so there'd also be zero lag.
@flamesoulis: This also makes me think, "Hey, we bake images and models. Why not audio?"
@marcusllewellyn: Optional though, please. I mean less control really just makes things worse, so as long as we can still toggle, then perfect.

@marcusllewellyn: Images make sense since progressive loading is either a working or not working system. Audio can already be streamed, even in basic MP3 or OGG format.

If we wanted to play nicely with audio for most efficient loading, it'd most likely be WAV or RAW files and... I'm pretty sure no one wants to go back to that anytime soon.

@flamesoulis: I see your point. However, context is everything, and different assets can have different bake (optimization) attributes. As you said, OGG, MP3 and even FLAC can all be streamed. The optimization here might be compression for bandwidth.
@revofire: Agreed 100%! I'm am all for creator choice and flexibility.

title: Put sounds in create menu
details: You should be able to add sounds to a world without needing to code. Sounds should be an item in the create menu that lets you create a sound entity kind of like you can create a light entity. Should be options for volume and what triggers the sound or having it loop all the time. Should also be able to stream to a sound object from computer to allow playing music in a zone while avatar can also talk.

comments.value:
What if you could also define which channels to play (Left, Right, Both, none) and then having the same options on children of the sound entity, then you could make a "real" stereo setup.
Actually, it could even be 6, 8 or 24 channels!
Independent attenuation settings would also be nice.

@silverfish: I think a better setup at that point would be channel positions, channel rotations, and channel follow.

Position: What position should the channel come from?
Rotation: What rotation should the channel be pointed (if not omnidirectional)?
Follow: Should the positions follow something? If so, should it follow the parent entity or the avatar? Should rotation be locked globally or locked locally?

In some theory, you can do this with different objects, but synchronization is nearly impossible.
I would like to be able to put original sound effects up in the marketplace without them needing to be pre scripted into something.
@lathe: I put a whole bunch of individual sounds in the marketplace, properly scripted, and they were all rejected. Apparently they don't want sounds in the marketplace.
This makes sense to us, too.   Will create sound entity as described here.
@dustywizard-1: Hey there can you email me the sounds that were rejected?  I don't think that is our policy.

@philip-47: The only issue I could forsee is making audio injectors redundant. Given that avatar entities have a set limit, this could pose issues with some projects, but also make certain ones work better. If a sound is meant to follow something, an audio entity could solve this (parent to the object being followed) and injectors being used for stationary script effects.

That being said, both injector and entity should have the same properties, but if that's the case, wouldn't that become a situation of local entities vs overlays?
@philip-47: Sure, I'll forward you the thread with the rejection discussion. Assume you are philip@highfidelity.com?

title: Easier Way to Purchase Place Name with HFC
details:
Currently, to purchase a place name with HFC you must set up an appointment with the banker to transfer HFC to them in exchange for a coupon code. You then have to enter this coupon on the website to purchase the place name outside of VR.

I tried this yesterday and hit on a couple of snags:

-	First, I learned the Oculus client does not implement the tablet UI in the Inventory app to conduct HFC transfers (I filed this as a bug). 

-	Then, it was an awkward experience between the banker and I for him to give me the coupon code. I asked if there was a way for him to e-mail it to me and he said that wasn’t something available to him. So instead he wrote it on a text box and held up a sign with the code. I took a snapshot of it and saved it to my desktop. Of course, as an image this means I can’t just copy/paste it into the website.

-	Outside of VR, I then went to use the coupon code and the system informed me the coupon code was invalid. Now, the banker had just assured me he had a fresh batch of coupons but I didn’t think anything of it at the time. I contacted support and provided screenshots of the coupon code provided in-world and the error shown on the website when using the same code. They responded quickly with a new coupon code which worked. The support rep mentioned that the banker may have some stale coupons.

Suggestions:
I do like the personal touch of meeting with a banker in a nice environment. It gives the transaction a tangible feeling. I’d be great if the banker could easily fire off an e-mail with the coupon code for easy copy/pasting.

As an alternative, it’d be even more convenient if in the tablet UI where there is already an option to purchase a coupon with HFC would allow the purchase of a place name coupon. I asked the banker if this was an option and he informed me the coupon systems are different. Allowing the purchase from the tablet would avoid the need to set up a time to meet with the banker if it’s hard to find a good time that works.

Lastly, another option would be to have place name coupons available for purchase in the marketplace. This would make the process familiar to those who have already purchased from the marketplace or make it a great introduction to doing so.

Another enhancement to the above suggestions would be if upon purchase the system would recognize the coupon in the user’s inventory and allow it to be applied at purchase time automatically without having to enter the code. 

Furthermore, the next level would be allowing the user to choose the place name upon purchase in-world, allowing one to conduct the entire transaction without having to take off the VR headset.

title: Model Entities should use the origin point stored in the model file.
details:
High Fidelity should no longer reset the origin point of all models to the median geometry point. It should use the original origin point stored in the FBX/OBJ/GLTF file.

This is abnormal behavior not found in literally any other game engines, and it adds an enormous level of frustration. 

If someone creates a large, highly detailed city in Blender with everything placed where it's supposed to be (all at the same origin, 0,0,0), they should be able to import all of that and KEEP it at that location once it's in High Fidelity. But that currently doesn't happen - instead, we're forced to re-position everything all over again, because the origin points of models are completely different once in High Fidelity.

High Fidelity should behave more like Unreal, Unity, etc. in this aspect. It should respect the origin point stored in our model files (fbx, gltf, obj), not change it without even asking us if that's we want.

You could even add a toggle switch in the model entity properties to keep the old behavior, if for some strange reason that's what you actually want. The vast majority of 3D artists will tell you they don't.  They'd rather position everything in their favorite 3D editor that they're already used to. If we could just position everything in Blender instead, and keep them in that position after import into HiFi, we'd never even have to touch HiFi's own build tools.

title: Improve media playback in High Fidelity Qt
details: Could you add support for open h.264 and other codecs in the hifi qt engine or could you implement a media entity using QT Multimedia module. This would use codecs that already on your  operating system.

comments.value: We love this idea! We're looking into it.

I thought I would flesh this out a bit more with some of my experience exploring the technical side of this topic.

The Chromium Embedded Framework (CEF) that Qt uses for our browser supports closed codecs with a recompile of the QtWebEngine component. It even allows for Cisco's openh264 library to be dynamically linked, easing legal worries. Unfortunately, that's the only patented codec that can be dynamically linked in the Windows platform. CEF uses VideoLan's libraries for all of the other codecs, and on Windows there is no way to dynamically link these and offer them as a separate download for the user. You can do this for Linux, however.

The alternative when staying with Qt components is to make use of QtMultiMedia and create a dedicated media entity. The upside to this approach is that no codecs need be provided by High Fidelity. In this case, Qt uses the operating system's underlying media engine to output video or audio. This means WMF or Directshow on Windows, gstreamer on Linux, or AVFoundation on Mac.

Of course there's a catch, at least on Windows. QtMultiMedia defaults to using Directshow, which isn't ideal. To make things as simple as possible for end users, WMF needs to be the default engine.
